results.abstract: The "Taxi" and "Who's the Boss?" star talks about teaching 10th-grade English in his reality series "Teach: Tony Danza."

headline.main: That's Mr. Danza to You: Tony Danza Goes Back to School for His Reality Show

results.snippet: The "Taxi" and "Who's the Boss?" star talks about teaching 10th-grade English in his reality series "Teach: Tony Danza."
results.lead_paragraph: Even if you never tuned in to "Taxi" and didn't care to know "Who's the Boss?," it's hard not to feel bad for Tony Danza in the first episode of his new A&E reality series, "Teach: Tony Danza," in which he leaves Hollywood to become a 10th-grade English instructor at Northeast High School in Philadelphia. In the debut installment, which will be shown Friday and which Alessandra Stanley reviews here, Mr. Danza is buffeted by strict administrators, outsmarted by his own students and - in a confessional scene that has dogged him throughout the promotion of the series - he breaks down and cries to the camera. (It's O.K., Mr. Danza, you're still the boss to us.)

results.abstract: Natalie Angier Basics column explores use of STEM, acronym for Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics; contends that it is flawed and ineffective way to define many facets of science education; drawing (M)

headline.main: STEM Education Has Little to Do With Flowers

results.snippet: The letters stand for Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics, but it has some branding issues. And is it even a brand worth saving?
results.lead_paragraph: If you want to talk about bolstering science and math education in this country, I'll gladly break out my virtual pompoms and go rah. Who wouldn't? Our nation's economy, global allure and future tense all depend on the strength of its scientific spine. But mention the odious and increasingly pervasive term ''STEM education,'' and instead of cheerleading gear, I reach for my ... pistil. In my disgruntlement, I am not alone.

results.snippet: Events for children around the city.
results.lead_paragraph: Rose Center 10th Anniversary Celebration On Sunday children can eat ''cosmic cake'' and sing ''Happy Birthday'' to salute an appropriately cosmic event: the 10th anniversary of the Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History. But implicit in the festivities is a celebration of a much bigger birthday, whose cake -- if it existed -- would require its own museum and about 14 billion candles.

results.abstract: Op-Ed article by former astronaut Russell Schweickart argues for detection-and-deflection program that could give millions of humans on Earth fighting chance against hit from asteroid; contends that mere $300 million addition to NASA budget would, over next decade, allow for full inventory of dangerous near-Earth asteroids and development and testing of deflection capacity that could save planet; drawing (M)
results.snippet: How to keep near-Earth objects from hitting us.
results.lead_paragraph: Sonoma, Calif. A FEW weeks ago, an asteroid almost 30 feet across and zipping along at 38,000 miles per hour flew 28,000 miles above Singapore. Why, you might reasonably ask, should non-astronomy buffs care about a near miss from such a tiny rock? Well, I can give you one very good reason: asteroids don't always miss. If even a relatively little object was to strike a city, millions of people could be wiped out.
